'''''Rhizomarasmius undatus''''' ([[synonym (taxonomy)|syn]]. '''''[[Marasmius]] undatus''''') is a small mushroom which grows on fern [[rhizomes]].<ref name=Antonín/><ref name=FungaNordica/><ref name=SF/>

==Description==
The species can be described as follows:<ref name=Antonín/><ref name="FungaNordica"/><ref name=Courtecuisse/>
*The cap has a powdery covering (a [[pruina]]), is initially whitish and convex and later becomes brownish grey and expands to be flat.  It grows to about 2.5 cm in diameter.
*The gills are whitish and distant, and broadly [[Lamella (mycology)#Classification|adnate]] to the stem, or slightly [[Lamella (mycology)#Classification|decurrent]]. The spore powder is white.
*The rigid stem can grow to about 12 cm long by about 2 mm in diameter. It is white at the top and dark brown to black lower down, with a [[pruina|puinose]] covering of short white hairs.
*The smell and taste are not distinctive.
*The spores are lemon-shaped to ellipsoid and measure roughly 9-12 µm x 5-7 µm.

==Naming and related species==
The [[botanical name|species epithet]] ''undatus'', meaning "wavy", is the past participle of the Latin verb "undo" (= "I undulate").<ref name=Lewis/>

This species was originally described in 1836 as ''Agaricus undatus'' by [[Miles Joseph Berkeley]].  As it happened, in 1838 the famous mycologist [[Elias Magnus Fries]] defined a completely different mushroom (now ''Entoloma undatum'') under the same name, but due to the nomenclatural rules of precedence, that definition is illegitimate.  This was confirmed when in 1849 Fries renamed Berkeley's fungus with the combination ''Marasmius undatus'', a name which was current for more than a century.  Then in 2000 it was one of the two initial species with which [[Ron Petersen|R. H. Petersen]] created the new genus ''[[Rhizomarasmius]]'', the other one being the type species ''R. pyrrhocephalus''.<ref name=SF/><ref name=Petersen/>

==Ecology and distribution==
This mushroom grows on [[rhizomes]] of bracken ([[Pteridium aquilinum]]) and probably other ferns.<ref name=Antonín/><ref name=FungaNordica/>  It is widespread but rare in northern and western Europe and has been reported from North Africa, North America, and the [[Altai mountains]].<ref name=Antonín/><ref name=Courtecuisse/><ref name=MycoDB/>
